080148.question: So, I've been trying analyse the time signature(s) of "Movie Star". I think it's mostly a 3/4+6/4 additive meter instead of 9/4. Is that how you were counting/feeling it or am I wrong? I was thinking something like this: Intro: 4x (3/4+6/4) Verse1: 2x (3/4+6/4) | 4x 3/4 Verse2: 2x (3/4+6/4) | 4x 3/4 Chorus1: 2x (3/4+6/4) Verse3: 2x (3/4+6/4) | 4x 3/4 Verse4: 2x (3/4+6/4) | 3x 3/4 | 4/4 Chorus2: 2x (3/4+6/4) Chorus3: (3/4+6/4) | 3/4 | 4/4 Bridge: 3x 3/4 | 4/4 | 3x 3/4 | 4/4 | 4/4 Verse5: 2x (3/4+6/4) | 4x 3/4 Verse6: 2x (3/4+6/4) | 3x 3/4 | 4/4 Chorus4: 2x (3/4+6/4) Chorus5: 2x (3/4+6/4) Outro: 5x (3/4+6/4)
080148.answer: i was hearing the main figure as 4+5. the verse for me is: 4+5, 4+5, 3+3, 4+2 4+5, 4+5, 3+3, 4+2 or: 4+5, 4+5, 3+3, 4+2 4+5, 4+5, 3+3, 4+3 the bridge would be: 3,3,4,3 3,3,4...and however much is left all chorus/vamps are 4+5. as you've noted there is likely a quick exception when ditching into the bridge

081633.question: just wondering, how did you make the globe rotation effect on hotewig? sorry, i can just imagine how tiresome it must be to receive these kind of questions
081633.answer: after trying many different strategies, i ended up doing it all with the camera, in a particle system centered on the globe, where the camera was the only particle. in most cases i only keyframed the particle system, and the camera, not the globe. this would be for most things from humans onward. for the earlier shots, a variety of different techniques were being tried. and for some of the north pole shots i may have had to spin the earth separately to avoid going haywire .... or for some of those polar shots i may have actually parented the camera system to another particle system to get a different axis of rotation going

081662.question: Dear Bill(y): When making songs, do you ever check other songs for reference (or chords idk), cuz when I do, I listen to the song so much that I forget the song that I was making, especially if the song I listened to was bopping...
081662.answer: the song you are making has never existed before, and it's brand new. so it means you haven't heard it very many times. so of course you may forget it. that's why it's so important to write new ideas down in sufficient detail to fully know how they go. of course you're going to forget, because it's brand new and you haven't heard it before. not writing it down is pretty careless, in my opinion. i realize it is often possible to just remember new ideas fine, but on the other hand there can be a lot of agony if you think you might remember but you're not sure. i need to know for sure. always write it down. in my view that is the only professional option

081854.question: your dedication to getting things done honestly amazes me. martin molin often talks about delayed gratification; he's been working on an extremely complex marble machine for the past 3 and a half years and he's been talking about how it's hard to stay motivated when you're working on something for so long and you don't get to see the finished product until the end. but even he does weekly build logs, which is a regular form of creative output. You, on the other hand, spent almost a year working exclusively on HotEWIG with no output whatsoever. and you're doing something similar right now, except you don't even really seem to have a solid, set end goal this time. there's no one big project you'll get to release at the end of this that will make you feel satisfied like all of that hard work culminated into this one big thing. how do you do it? I can't possibly imagine sitting down and spending over a year teaching myself a skill without even a pro ject in mind. basically you are incredible and i would like to know your secrets
081854.answer: yes i do, i am doing the filmmaking revolution. i'm sure other people are doing it too, because that's just what time it is 1 isn't nearly enough things to release. if i only did 1 thing, then why did i even make a website. you get what i'm saying sometimes if i feel like 1 department or avenue of development is taking too long and i feel disconnected from it, it can be good to do an overview list of all the different things that need to be taken care of and how they tie into the big picture. as soon as you return to the big picture all the original motivations should come through loud and clear all projects are in mind. my mind is overwhelmedly overflowing with projects. that is surely how i got into this mess my secret is telling all the secrets, not necessarily when they are asked, but at other times

081965.question: every time i listen to your music i get really inspired. i just wanna know, how do you manage to have such a variety of sounds in your songs?
081965.answer: the trick is, instead of finding a sound for each place in the song, find a place in the song for each sound. DON'T put it if it doesn't fit, but just keep searching from place to place until it really fits. doesn't count if it doesn't fit. with this technique you have to keep searching until it really fits, but it does still also have to go somewhere. but NOT anywhere, has to fit. but it has to go somewhere. i hope i have explained that properly. Also, you still have to do the song's core with fewer and more reliable basic instruments, but the decorations should be done on a 'what then when' basis rather than a 'when then what' basis. this is for production. writing usually goes the other way (when-what)

082072.question: How do you go from writing a small tune or loop of a track to a fully fledged song?
082072.answer: usually what seems to work best (for me) is to make sure you fully write the song first, before really recording it. know exactly how it goes, and for exactly how long. Doing a full recording/arrangement of a song is crazy enough, and if you don't know how the song goes you'll surely crumble. unless you are doing the type of arrangement that can be delivered in its final form in real time. It's like building a house. you have to know the specific plans of the house before building it, unless you have technology so advanced that the house can be built instantly, in which case yes you could definitely improvise the house

082169.question: how do you make an arrangement feel more full and less empty? i add some melody and then some chords and try to stick some bass in there and by the time the drums get in it all feels like plain bread with no real meat or energy to it
082169.answer: add too much, then it will seem too full if you start with songs that are extremely short (1 to 2 seconds) you can easily tend to it fully and make it perfect, and find out what works very quickly, because you only have a tiny span of time to work with. then make the next song slightly longer.... A crisis will set in somewhere around when you get to 18 seconds or more, but by then you will have created a lot of great recordings, so you'll have the experience needed to take on the new challenge by that point

082331.question: can you teach us how to prime factorize numbers other than the basics (divisibility by 2, 3 and 5) and the "left method"?
082331.answer: sure. there are many different levels of strategies. essentially what i do is, after breaking down the 2 3 and 5, then you're left with sort of an "almost prime" number. and then you have to check every prime number, starting with 7. The basis of the technique is, you are allowed to manipulate the target number (the 'almost prime' number) by multiples of the checker number (such as 7), in any way you want, and the target number will still retain its status of WHETHER OR NOT it is a multiple of 7. So for example, if your target is 6737, we can add or subtract 7 as many times as we want and IF 6737 was divisible by 7, any result you get from adding or subtracting 7s will ALSO be a multiple of 7. And similarly, if 6737 was NOT div by 7, it will retain its status as NOT being divisible by 7, no matter how many transformations you do. So it will retain its status of 7 or non7, no matter how many times you add/subtract 7s, OR divide by anything (as long as it stays a whole number). So that's the first guideline of the strategy, but that still doesn't sound too easy..... But the trick is this: your 'almost prime' number (target) that you're working with, it's always gonna end in 1,3,7, or 9. That's just the truth, if you've already gotten all the 2's and 5's out of it, it has to end in 1 3 7 or 9. WHICH MEANS, it is ALWAYS 1 or 3 away from a MULTIPLE OF 10. So, ..... what's also true, is, EVERY smaller prime number (the 'checkers' you'll use), also HAS to be 1 or 3 away from a multiple of 10. they simply all are, that's how prime numbers are. SO, here's what makes this work--- if your checker is 1 away from a mult of 10, for example, you can ALWAYS get it to switch to 3 away, if you triple it. And the other way around, if your checker is 3 away from a mult of 10, you can triple it and it ALWAYS switches to 1 away. SO...... therefore, you can always add or subtract the checker, OR its triple, to even it off to a mult of 10. And that result, will STILL be the same status for that factor, after the transformation, and you can easily drop the zero, and now the number has shrunk. and you keep doing that until you recognize it. So that's the starting point-- so for example, 6737 is your target, say you're checking 7, just subtract 7. and you have 6730, and you can drop the zero and have 673. And if 6737 was a multiple of 7, then 6730 has to be too, and 673 has to be too. Now you can do it again, you can add 7 and it's 680, drop the zero is 68, this i already know is NOT a multiple of 7 (i already recognize 68 as 17 times 4), but let's say you couldn't see that, you have some options... i can see 28 you could subtract from 68 to even it off, then you'd get 40 == 4, and i think you can easily see that 4 is NOT a multiple of 7, so by extension, you know the original number 6737 was ALSO not a multiple of 7, because we've only made legal transformations -- adding or subtracting only multiples of 7 or dividing (by anything). Going back to when we were at 68, you could also just divide by 2, get 34, and again, to get 17. which hopefully you can recognize as not a mult of 7, but in case you can't (??) you can subtract 7 you're left with 10, drop the zero is 1 == NOT 7. So 7 is ruled out. Then you would move on to 11. So 11 doesn't match right away, because 11 is 1-away (from 10) and 6737 is 3-away (from mult of 10). So you can triple 11 and automatically get it to fit: 33 is 3 away (from a mult of 10), so you can cleanly add it to 6737 to get 6770, drop the zero is 677. Now here you could go with 33 again, but if you know how 11 works you'll be able to spot 77 right away. And you can knock that right off, and you're left with 6, which you can easily recognize as NOT a multiple of 11, so by extension you know the target number was not a multiple of 11. This is the basis of the technique, but as you do it you learn new tricks all the time. You can also go from the left, which is sometimes even easier, but i'll wait until another time to explain the left mode although maybe you already know it. Some other tricks, which you'll find quickly, are like easier versions of some checkers which are also legal but amazingly simple to see. For example, for 29, if you need it to be 3 away, but 87 is too ugly for some reason, you can use 203. 203 is a legit multiple of 29, and it's usually easier to use than 87-- unless your target already has 87 visibly very obviously. 301 is a great one for 43. 901 is great for 53. 1003 is great for 59. Another great trick is to use 2001 for both 23 AND 29. ever since i discovered that i use it every time, because it knocks out 2 numbers at once. 1001 can also be used for 7,11, and 13, but i'm not sure if that's ever actually eaiser, because 7 11 and 13 are all so small that they usually breeze right by. Often in the early stages, you can knock off 2 numbers at once, for example if your target is 1911, ... you can knock off 11 and get 19, and knock off 19 and get 11... since 11 and 19 are both there together it is clear that they're not compatible with each other, so you can knock both of them off. Another important thing to remember, is that as the checkers get higher, the likelyhood that you'll find a match decreases. So you are the most likely to find a match with 7, 11, 13, etc and as you get higher it gets less and less likely, and more likely your target is prime. So it's kind of anti climactic in that way. I guess you could do it the other way around, but it would tend to take much more time because you would be looking in unlikely places first. And the other very important thing to remember, is how to know when to stop -- and you know this from square roots. you can estimate usually. If you check all the checkers in order, and you don't find a match, you never have to go any higher than the square root of the target. The reason for this, is that let's say... for example with 6737, for that target you should only have to check checkers up to the sq root of 6737. You can approximate that if you know 64 as 8 squared. you can estimate that 80 squared is 6400 (basically just do it without the zeros, and know that the zeros on the square number should be twice as many). So 80 squared is 6400, and 90 squared should be 8100. So, 6737 is somewhere in between, probably closer to 80 sq, so you know that 83 squared is about as high as you'll have to go, and 89 is already way over. So you only have to go to 89. and the reason you know this is because, let's say, you've checked all the checkers UP TO 83 already, and not found a match. Well, IF you checked 89, and found a match, what would its partner be? in other words, 89 times SOMETHING would have to be 6737.... but that's impossible, because we already know that 83 times 83 is LESS, so for 89 times something to be MORE than 6737, you'd need the other multiplier to be LESS than 83, but that's impossible because you already checked everything. So IF you checked everything and haven't made a mistake, then you should be totally sure that the target is prime by the time you reach approximately the square root of it. So just to quickly knock this one out so i can see if there are any other surprises to show you, we were at 13, so 6737, add 13 is 6750, drop the zero is 675, when it gets to a 5 you can go with a mult of 13 that works with 5 (such as 65) or if it's easier you could double 675 and knock off a zero (that would be the same as dividing by 5). Or on this one you could just divide by 25 if that is easier for you... but let's say you wanna just subtract 65, so that's 61 and def not a mult of 13 (mult of 13 would be 65 of course) so 13 is out. So 6737, checking 17, easily subtract 17, you get 672. And at any point, if the number looks hella even, just go ahead and divide by 2 if you want. The more parts of the number look even, the easier it is. in this case you'd wanna look at it like 6 72. and just cut each in half, hopefully you'd recognize 72 going in half to 36. so 6 72 would be 3 36. Now 336, can effortlessly be divided by 3, because the digits discretely and exclusively are all multiples of 3. so 112, which i know as 7 mixed with 2's etc, but just cut it in half a few times and you'll see it (no 17). SO.... 6737 checking 19, well, subtract the triple (57), or i might as well say the left method, i see 67 all the way on the left, and you can swap that out for 10 because 57 is 10 under it. This left method follows different rules so i didnt wanna say it just yet, but it's always good to have a second option...so you swap out 6737 to 1037, ... then if you know 95 (19x5) you can do another left swap, swapping 103 out for 8 (it works with any number of consecutive digits from the left), so you can swap 103 for 8 because 95 is hiding just 8 under 103. so from 1037, replace the 103 with 8, so now you have 87. If you didn't recognize that as 29x3, then you could subtract 57 (19's triple) to get 30 and clearly is not 19. so 19 is out. 6737, just add 23, is 676, divide by 2, if you group it like 6 76 you should be able to see it, if you are familiar with 76 going to 38, you'd get 3 38. ... 338. Or, if you dont like that you can just stick with 676 and work 23 with it, using its DOUBLE, 46, subtract 46 from 676 and get 63, which might be known as 7x9 or even easier you'll know you can't have another 23 multiple ending in 3 anywhere near here. Or if you had stuck with 338 from before, divide again nah fuck it it's got 2 odd numbers in it. Numbers get harder to cut in half the more consecutive odd numbers they have. So anyway 23 is out. 6737, checking 29, my trick is 203, ... add it, .. get 6940, drop the zero, 694. divide by 2, grouping as 6 94 because i know 94 -- so that's 3 47.... 347. add 203 again because it fits, is 550 , drop zero is 55 clearly just in 11 land so 29 is out. 6737, doing 31, doesn't fit so triple it, which is 93 which is pretty easy if you just think of it as 100 and delete the 7... so 683. then subt 93, 590, 59, i know 59 as prime, or maybe you'd know 62 as 31 which is close so you know it's not it. 31 out. 6737, well that's just too easy, knock off 37, you get 67. so you can knock off both 67 and 37, if you can remember that by the time you get to 67. ok 6737, so checking 41 you may have to triple. it's 123. What i sometimes do is first get whether you're gonna add or subt, then just level everything off first, then do the add/subt.. So you know youre gonna add, then think of 123 as 12, and think of 6737 as 674. 674 plus 12 is 686. div by 2 easliy with discrete digits, is 343. you'll be subtracting 123, they both have 3s at the end so just ditch them first then do it, so it's 34 minus 12, clearly NOT your checker number (41) so it's good to know where you're going because you can totally skip the details on 34 minus 12 cuz you know it will never be a multiple of 41. Next is 43, add it to 6737 is 678, div by 2, hopefully you know 78 in 13 land, goes to 39, so 678 div by 2 is 3 39. 339 div by 3, discretely breaks down by digit easily to 113. Already know that's prime, but in case you don't, just subtract 43 and you already know that's gonna even off to a 1 digit number, so you dont even have to even bother thinking of it. 43 is out. 6737, next checker is 47 -- At some point you'll have to start checking the checkers, as they get too high for you to already know them, for me that doesn't really happen until around 320, that's probably because i've been working on doing everything from 99999 downwards as a sleeping technique, which puts the square root somewhere around 320, so i'm pretty familiar with everything up to 320 by now, ... so anyway, checking 47, in 6737, subt 47 is 669, easily div by 3 is 223, subt 43 again evens off to 18 so no. 6737, next is 53, add it, is 679, you'll need to triple 53 to use 159, but i personally hate that and i found 901 works instead for 53, so 679 plus 901 is 1580, 158, div by 2 is 79, which i know as prime, but if you don't, it's clearly recognizable as not a multiple of 53 because 53x2 is obviously already over 100. so 53 is out. 6737, next would be 59, so you'd have to either triple it, or use the trick i found which is 1003. so that makes 7740, to 774, now here, you could probably divide by 2 reasonably easily, but i just hate dealing with odd digits so much that i'd probably rather just take 1003 and double it and use that. so you can add 2006 to 774 pretty easily,.... 2774 then 2780. so 278. divide by 2 is 139, which i know as prime, but if you don't have that, you can just subtract your checker (59) and in fact, if you are too lazy to calculate 139-59 (i know i'd rather not) you really don't have to, i think there are multiple ways you can automatically know that it's not gonna be 59. the last digit is gonna be zero for sure. also 139 is loosely in the realm of 2x59 but it would have to be even for that to work. there's always little contextual tricks you can find to escape the pain of doing awkward calculations. so 59 is out. So next is 61, in 6737, i hate using 61's triple, so i'd go from the left-- looking at 67 you can see 61 is nearby under it -- by the way this left trick only works when you see the checker UNDER some string on the left, not over. i mean you could do it with over too but the math would be much uglier. so swap 67 for 6, and it's 637. then again easily from the left, replace the 63 with 2, so 27. so no. Next is 67, just knock it right off. 71, 71 is kind of ugly, the triple is decent, it's 213, so 6737 plus 213 is 695. times 2 is 139. and the checker was 71, well, in that range, 139 is in the right range to be a double of 71, but it's not even, so it can't be a double. So you can rule it out that way. sometimes if you step back you can see the obvious. in a way, as the numbers get larger, sometimes it's actually easier to recognize obviously when something is NOT a multiple of them, beccause there are fewer numbers that ARE, and you can narrow it down based on characteristics (ending digit) or range. So, 6737, checking 73... add it... not fun.. but it will end in 1 (this is from knowing 73+27 as a pair)... so 681. that's just 127x3, so no. checking 79, this one really sucks. This is one of the most miserable ones if you need a triple. i always get 237 and 267 confused. But, it's 237. so that actually fits quite easily with 6737. it's gonna go to 65, so that's out. Now we're at 83, which is really approximately the square root of 6737. so if 83 works, it would HAVE to be a square, because it can't pair with anything higher than 83 or else it would go way above 6737. And actually you can tell it won't be 83 squared, because 83 squared has to end in 9, and 6737 does not. But, it's good to check anyway because if you made a mistake on ANYTHING up to this point, then you could be looking at higher numbers, to pair with whatever lower one you missed. so to check 83 just in case, 6737, gotta add it... level it first... 8 plus 674. is 682. in half is 341. You can probably get this easily from range, but i will add the triple, 249, which is easy for me to remember, so like 34 plus 25 is ... urg, see that right there is just unnecessarily hard for me. but look, it's not gonna be nearly as big as 83. so without even doing 34 plus 25 you can still see that it's definitely not 83. so therefore it's ruled out. So that rules out everything, so 6737 is prime. however, let's say it was 6713, and you had found a match, 7? 672 yes i see it, minus 42 is 630 is 63, so then you have a match, so you have to work backwards, so 63 would be 9 (x7) so you have 9, so then it was 672, so that was plus 42 which in terms of 7s is 6. (6x7=42). so you had 9, then 6. but the 6 is in the next digit so it's 96. then from 672 it was 7 under that-- i should clarify... we're adding digits, so it's 6720, and 6713 was 7 under that. You basically have to retrace your steps from how you found the match. so it would be 960, but 1 under that. so 959. Then, after you've found that match, and divided it out, (and hopefully remembered that you have already taken 7 out), then you keep checking in THAT number (959), as the new target number, and you keep going through the checkers from where you left off, BUT you have to check the same checker again. Because it may have 7 in it twice. You don't have to check anything lower, because you've already DIS proved those, but just because you found a match at 7 still doesn't disprove the possibility of finding MORE 7s. so you have to keep checking the same one to make sure it's not a double or even triple match (7x7x7, etc). So, 959, i can easily see 49 being easy to subtract, that's 91, which i happen to know is 13x7, but if you didn't know that you could clearly see it by subtracting 21 and getting the match that way (70, =7). So working with 91, knowing that's 7x13, we express it all in terms of 7s, so that's 13, ... then what next, .. it was 959, so you have to add 7 (7x7) to 13, BUT in the next digit, ... so 137. So basically 137 is where we are after finding and removing 2 matches, both 7s, from the original target number. so in otherwords, we've discovered that the target number (6737) divided by 7, twice, is 137. i already know that's prime, but if you didn't, then you can subtract 7 again, get 13, knock out 7, and keep checking, which will be over very quickly because with 137, you only have to check up to 12 (12 squared is 144, already too high). So that leaves only 1 checker left, so you'd check 11, do it from the left, swap 13 with 2, and it's 27, clearly not a mult of 11. So if you can remember the breakdown, that would be 137x7x7. Hope that helps. It can be important to set boundaries also with this, i typically only use it as a sleep exercise, or, if i happen to be stuck waiting in line somewhere or stranded somewhere where i have absolutely no tangible ability to work on anything else (which pretty much would only occur in a scenario where i am incapable of writing anything down).... it's important to set boundaries because this is probably not a very useful endeavor otherwise, especially with the availability of calculators. But it is a decent brain exercise in problem solving, in some ways, and it can be calming

082354.question: hi bill. i have to say, i really enjoy your music. i have advanced music theory knowledge and your music continues to intrigue me. i guess living under a rock pays off, huh? the freshness, originality, and flow is just amazing; it truly sounds like your music is coming out of independent creativity and not by some corporate bullshit. that's what music is all about, right? that being said, you are one of my biggest inspirations. i can play several instruments, but i can't seem to go farther than cover some songs; i don't know where to start for original creations that i can be satisfied with. i've seen some in depth analysis of your music: https://www.hooktheory.com/theorytab/view/bill-wurtz/i-just-did-a-bad-thing https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-0Bw2Rg5nFQ https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1c15ecCCmbs and it seems like your music is very complicated. you've mentioned that every song for you is planned out in whole bef orehand, but for me, i can't seem to come up with anything that is melodic or harmonically satisfying to me. do you have any suggestions for me? appreciate it!
082354.answer: holy school picture re-take day, you are very friendly for someone in your situation, i can think of 2 things to suggest. 1, try using words some how. Music can escalate the power of words, immensely. and words can escalate the power of music, immensely. Sometimes without one or the other, things can be aimless. If you don't want to use words, then you could try using a picture. Music also can do just fine when it's being used to enhance a picture. Music and non-music are a match forged deep within the origins of the universe. And the other thing i would recommend, specifically if you think you have a fine grasp on what notes and chords are gonna sound like, grab some staff paper and go to a room, a library is good because you have no access to an instrument, but i dunno if there's any real libraries nowadays, but just somewhere where you are sequestered with no access to instrument. just your mind, and paper. and a singular pitch reference is ok, but come on, you can remember your favorite songs well enough to snag an absolute pitch right? or maybe there's an elevator bell in the room that you can learn. Anyway, absolute is not even important here really. try to use words too. Write the lead sheet, with melody and chords, lyrics, the whole thing. As long as you are comfortable that you have the ability to know what it sounds like without using an instrument, which i suspect you do, the idea of writing a song entirely like that, just in your mind, and writing it down immediately on paper into finality, it can make you feel kinda powerful and also desperately insane, which is always good for writing

082416.question: how do you make sure sounds are more buried in the mix? i hear a lot of fun details like percussion or sfx or cool background chords in your music that i dont notice unless i focus on but they add to the overall vibe or replayability or whatever, but usually when i add any element to a song it tends to default be way too PRESENT and take up too much attention when i actually want it to just chill in the background. any advice?
082416.answer: turn them down? i think this might be arranging and not mixing ...... Usually, and this may surprise you, but usually the notes that you are hearing are actually not very many notes at a time. Even in a big arrangement, usually not very many things actually happen at the same time. and the things that do are usually in direct physical reenforcement of each other (i.e. the same note). There's usually less than 5 notes at a time, and less than 3 things happening rhythmically at a time

082451.question: people don't incentivize reading nearly as much as they should. they always say to "read more", but I find it almost unnecessary to read blocks of text that reveal the stories of others by making your eyes tired. how are you supposed to become smarter just by reading the stories of others, regardless of whether or not the story is legitimately interesting? like wow, I just have my brain expand a thousandfold by reading about a story that is completely irrelevant to my life. also, I find it difficult to maintain a well enough retention rate to "absorb" information in any piece of literature, as the education system's propaganda always expects us to do. and with my many years in participating in the education system, I have yet to acquire the proper "Lexile score" for my grade simply because the most incentive teachers give out would be to have my Lexile score be higher and just showing the results of reading a lot. hell, my grammar is terrible simply because schools, after all of their propaganda, have failed to give me enough valid reasoning for me to actively learn. but I am aware that reading is important, especially outside of the school circle. but the most you are supposed to do in school is to listen to the teacher and drain yourself of any critical and creative thinking abilities. those tasks don't require any book reading. so I should embark on a quest to find more reasons as to why I should read. do you have any better reasons as to why I should read? you seem like someone who has found out why
082451.answer: well..... on this page for example, if i didn't read i wouldn't know what your question was. and if you don't read, you're not gonna find out what my answer is. also not reading would make browsing the internet pretty difficult

082453.question: Hey Bill, I've been trying my hand at writing as of late, and I have all these great ideas for characters and character interactions, but I just can't seem to connect them all to the over-arching plot. Have you ever written any stories, and if so do you have any advice on how to bring them to fruition?
082453.answer: there is a common debate about whether you should try to think of the plot ('outline') before you write. as i am foraying more deeply into this issue, i am rapidly forming stronger opinions than i thought, in favor of the non-outline. Believe me, i've been trapped in a corner with no plot many times before, as can clearly be seen in my infantile attempts over the past few years, which is what makes me feel pressure to outline (i recall hitting a point of desperation somewhere over the Andes mountains). I think you will find some writers have to outline, some writers think you're supposed to outline, some writers are very good at outlining, sometimes it almost feels like most people assume you are supposed to outline. But ... there are some people who say when they outline it ruins it. Some people say they are hired to write stories, and they are required to do an outline, so they have to fake the outline, either by making a fake outline first and then ignoring it when they write the real thing, (and the bosses usually forget), or, by just writing the whole story first and then making a fake outline based on how the story actually turned out. Many many professional writers insist that you have to outline in order to get anywhere, and that seems true.... and i want to believe this......... but i keep having these realizations which put me further and further toward the non-outline side of the spectrum. here's an example, which i may or may not agree with in a few years from now, but i was noticing something: when i watch movies/films (like the kind you would see in the cinema back when that was a thing), the majority of those that i've seen, when i watch them for the first time, ......... extremely often i have no earthly idea what's going on for at least the first 30 minutes. The scenes may be great, and i am perfectly keen to enjoy great scenes and dialogue like music, even if i don't actually have any idea who these people are or what they're talking about, but still... somehow, in most of these cases, i just... think we're supposed to know what's going on. I think the writer assumes that it's more intelligible than it is.... because they think they've left enough clues as to what's going on. I don't know if i'm the only one, it could be just some kind of brain disfunction, but most movies seem to act like i'm supposed to know what the hell is going on, even though i don't. (again, this does not usually detract from the aesthetics of the scene and music of the dialogue, but somehow i still think we're probably supposed to know what's going on, at least slightly) Again, i may just be stupid, but i've noticed that if i see the movie for the second time, THEN it obviously works out perfectly, and everything is great and makes sense and thrives fully well......... because i have already watched the movie an entire time so i know what's going on. Maybe you see where i'm going with this................. suddenly i had a shocking realization. and you may disagree with this, and who knows, i may disagree with it later, but it seems perfectly clear to me currently..... which is that All these scenes are designed by someone who already knows what's going to happen. that's why it makes no sense to someone who doesn't know yet. And suddenly it occured to me that what MUST be done (at least on my watch, if i am writing) it became quite clear to me that the only fair way to actually avoid this problem is for the writer to actually not know what's going to happen. that seems like the most effective way for the writer and the reader to actually be on the same page and to enjoy and understand the same things. I'm sure there's other ways around this, but if you are asking me at this point i would say i'm leaning heavily toward the free side of the spectrum. that being said, i'm sure you are aware that i've had some blunders attempting to be on that side of the spectrum (exclusively blunders, for the most part, aside from times i resorted to non-fiction) but in my case i think the trick around that might be something as simple as having more than 1 character. which i strangely never really tried before, so we'll see what happens

082457.question: how do I use a click track if the tempo changes in my song?
082457.answer: most sequencers can do tempo changes. but if you are actually just recording without a sequencer but you want to use a click, then you can still record your own custom click. Record yourself singing the tempo through the transitions, and then use them to calibrate the transitions, and line the clicks up to that. after having picked the tempos you want, and recording them both and then moving them into place. but it is much more likely that your sequencer can do tempo changes

082708.question: Would you become a fine mist if given the option?

082709.question: how did you get the original inspiration for "got to know what's going on"? (love that song by the way)
082709.answer: i think we all just want to understand how the world really works, and what is really going on, and what everything is and means. i came up with the first line of the chorus, and many others, many years before i would have had the courage to take care of the entire songwriting, especially because dealing with a song where you only know the chorus, and then figuring out what comes before, is a very weird puzzle that i didn't learn how to do until years later. in fact i didn't even really have the courage to finish the chorus either, until years later. it was quite common for me to come up with quite normal sounding hooks and not know what to do with them, and back then (around 2010) my only strategy was to start at the beginning and go bonkers, from beginning to end. but there were many chorus-sounding figures that were generated at that time, such as 'i'm sad', 'i wanna go home', etc, which i didn't really know how to deal with. As of june 2017, recording songs regularly, my selection process was brute force random-number selection -- no pre-selection, no semi-finals, just get a randomly generated number out of 400 (or however many items there were in the list at the time) and you absolutely have to pick that one, no matter what it is. So that one came up and was still just a 1 line figure. so that's when the rest of it was written

082712.question: i never thought i would be here but i don't like using note letter notation , like C D F# bc i'm like goddamn i only Know where C is am i supposed to count the white notes like a child just to get a dumb name for a dumb chord which will just BE played WHEN i play it, and basically the only reason to even know what name it is is for """""""""""music""" ""theory"""""""""" which is just figuring out WHY things that already exist sound good, and not the actual direct study of how making those things actually works and happens, which most absolutely positively and all-encompassingly seems like the wrong approach to take when trying to be musiciany. but, um, i'm conflicted, for i think obvious reasons. do i need to crush san francisco with a giant ball of mercury and iron or is there another out here?
082712.answer: that's not really the reason for notation. mostly the reason for notation is to communicate with other musicians. Figuring out why things sound good is a whole different endeavor, which is impossible but also fun i think you should start using numbers instead of letters, so they always represent the same thing relative to the song. this is probably a better representation of how the music actually goes, and sounds. And most musicians do understand it, so you can communicate that way too. i believe the entire city of nashville was built on numbers, if i recall

082848.question: Hey bill if you wanna make your life easier when it comes to figuring out if something is a multiple of 7, there's a convenient way to use your subtract/add a multiple of 7 trick that makes it much easier. Say your number is 30583 for example. Now we know that 21 is a multiple of 7 right? That means anything times 21 is also a multiple of 7. So what we can do is just subtract the number by 21 times the last digit of the number, in this case 3. So 21*3=63 which means we can do 30583-63->30520 then divide by 10 to get 3052. Then repeat. 3052-42->3010->301 301-21->280->28 which is divisible by 7 which means 30583 is divisible by 7. Now whenever we are subtracting by 21 times the last digit and then dividing by 10, what we are essentially doing is taking the last digit, doubling it, then subtracting the rest of the number by t he doubl ed last digit. So like instead of doing 30583-63->30520->3058 what you can instead do is a short cut for 30583 and take the last digit 3, double it to get 6, and then subtract the rest of the number by that doubled digit, 3058-6->3052, and then just keep subtracting the rest of the number by the last digit doubled until you get to a number you know is divisible by 7.
082848.answer: i would just go to 3059, 301, 35. so 437

082902.question: Hey Bill, I really enjoy how unique your writing is, and the one man show type deal is so intriguing to me because of how much personal freedom and creativity it allows. After much pondering I've decided to give it a try on my own. I play several winds, strings, and drums decently well but have no experience in production whatsoever. Was thinking maybe getting my music out on YouTube. Any thoughts, ideas, or tips on learning production? (Btw I've chosen reaper for a DAW, because people said it's good and it's nice to trust them) thanks!
082902.answer: yes what i would recommend, in this case, and forgive me if you've heard me say this 10,000 times before, which i have, but my best advice for this situation which i recommend strongly is to start with extremely short pieces of music. Extremely short. like 3 seconds or less. because producing your own music from scratch is about as complicated as building a finished house that is ready for move-in. there are so many things and different categories of work and different departments you have to deal with, it seems impossible to learn to do all that stuff. 082904.question: How do I focus on making songs when every time I try and focus it feels like my body is acclimating to poison. Is it ever possible to truly just sit down and induce it?
082904.answer: hm, i'm wondering where you are in your relationship to the desire to do songwriting. in other words, why are do you want to write songs, has it ever happened before, etc.. For example, if it's the case the songs tend to throw themselves at you when you are least expecting, but yet you can't seem to 'induce' them, i can understand that and i have various things to suggest. If you've seemingly never had song ideas before of any kind, then i might recommend something different, and again would want to know more about your relationship to the desire of songwriting. And depending on your level of music experience vs word writing experience, i might recommend freestyling a lot in text-editors, or if your word writing experience is ahead of your music, then i might recommend improvising a lot on a chordal instrument, possibly while singing, there are all kinds of things which i might suggest depending on your background and how you have progressed so far

082984.answer: yes, but i think i missed the perfect opportunity. this is kind of a long story but hopefully you can follow... one time i was driving through a mandatory sobriety check point. they looked at my license and asked me to say the alphabet. But i've heard so many stories about police asking you to say the alphabet BACKWARDS, that in my mind i thought that's what they said. And it just so happens that as a child i familiarized myself with a fully functional version of the common ABC song, with backwards lyrics, so the alphabet is in reverse. So i have the backwards alphabet very readily commited to memory. So i started blasting through the backwards alphabet (not in song, just spoken) and i already got to about Q when he said 'whoa whoa whoa, no, forwards.' and he probably thought i was crazy. Everything worked out fine, but unfortunately i missed the opportunity to simply press play on the CD in the CD player, which happened to be a test mix of my 'Alphabet Shuffle' song, which i had been listening to moments before. i understand this story would have been better if i had actually done it, but for some reason it didn't seem like a good idea at the time

083187.question: I've got many things to do but I dont know which one to do first so I just end up doing nothing. Can you help me figure out a method of solving this? Thanks in advance
083187.answer: here's what i would recommend, based on similar long term problems i've had, and the best solution that has emerged. it's a hybrid randomization scheme. First, put all the items in a list. 2 different approaches come to mind- 1: using complete randomization to pick (computer generated random selection), but this might end up picking one that you actually don't really want to do. 2: 'just picking the one you want' clearly doesn't work, otherwise you wouldn't be in this situation. So i've found a hybrid system: the way it works is, first you go through the list and choose ones that you think are reasonable choices -- it's ok to pick as many as you want. Add these to a finalists list. then, immediately as soon as you finish making that list, do a random selection based on that new list. And that's your selection. If you don't end up choosing any for the finalists list, then go ahead and just do the random selection on the original list. i hope this helps. i think it is a solid system and it works for me, even in the face of extreme decision anxiety

084229.question: When a human being or other creature with opposable thumbs strums a guitar or similarly-shaped, differently-sized instrument, it's generally taught that their dominant hand is meant to be pressing down on the strings over the frets while their non-dominant hand strums the strings further down the body of the guitar. Wouldn't playing guitar be more effective if the musician was carefully constructing chords with their dominant hand while strumming with their non-dominant hand? I ask because I learned how to play a 'non-dominant hand' guitar and then a 'dominant hand' guitar upside-down and I am wondering if it is too late for me to change my ways. Also, if someone is ambidextrous, how do they pick which hand does what??
084229.answer: i'm quite sure it could be learned either way how late is it you'll probably play whatever instrument you have. and if you literally have exactly equal choice between the two, then you would probably weigh the advantages and disadvantages, some of which might be: right handed instruments will usually be easier to find. playing lefty will look more unique. playing the opposite way of the way the instrument was intended may make your playing very unique, yet that will also possibly create some slight blockades in communication when discussing playing technique with others who don't also play backwards

084243.question: I am trying to write songs but most ideas are extremely similar to your old jingles. maybe because ive spent an embarassingly long amount of time looking at them, or maybe because i enjoy them the most (my conspiracy theory is, it's a combination of both). how do i grow out of copying someone and thinking more originally?
084243.answer: there are 2 things you can do. listen to at least 100 other artists. then, besides that, try to write something that ABSOLUTELY none of those artists have ever done. to make this easier for yourself, temporarily waive the requirement that they are supposed to be 'good'. try to do something incorrect and horrendous with the music. What this does is it taunts the music gods, provokes them, and they will try to get their revenge by making the music good anyway. And you will see that the path it takes FROM that horrendous place, back to a more familiar place, will be very interesting, and still quite different from most things you've heard, while still being good

084288.question: Hey I want to make music. I already do, I've been for years, but I suck at all musical instruments I've tried at (for years), and at making music too. I'm very stressed by my personal and education stuff and as a result I always feel tired, leaving me with no energy to focus on any instrument enough to actually improve. Usually I play whatever I feel like, mess around which can be fun but on non-polyphonic instruments gets boring quickly. Also I suspect that this way I'm discouraged from trying new things (because in the beginning they won't be fun, as I will fail at them over and over again), so I don't improve. As you see I'm kinda desperate, but that desperation isn't good enough of a fuel: I've attempted a serious approach, playing exercises from a book everyday but after a month the results were scarce, then I was forced to slow down and now I'm back at the beginning again. Back at pointless wankery too. I don't really believe I'm gonna make it anymore. I'm thinking of quitting, and not just music. But that's just awful and I can't. I'm stuck, I don't know what to do. I've written folk tales, that didn't help. Maybe I should do something else, but at this point I've given too much to let go, and anyway if I'm this obsessed it's because I've had fun sometines, both listening, making and playing music. But it seems emotions vanish when I need them the most
084288.answer: ah yes, i could see that i'd say you won't even know how fun the game can be until you get some chords into your life SOMEHOW ah, right. you are seeing the mischievous nature of music. (well, not just music, ........ sometimes it seems almost everything in the world is that way, but that's another story). You could think of it like a playful pet, or friend. it honestly really likes you. you just have to be gentle and friendly with it. it will find you anyway. might even be fun to try to ignore it for a second and see if it comes bounding back clamoring for your attention

084338.question: I want to make music but every time I try to write something I end coming up with something that sounds super generic. What do you do to make your songs sound unique?

084403.question: Please help me, this is driving me crazy. What the hell time signature is Schism by Tool?? I swear to god it's 7/8 9/8 but others disagree. What do you hear? I trust your rhythmic wisdom
084403.answer: let me take a listen......... right, so i tend to hear that one as 5+7. so a quick 5 then a quick 7. but surely you might say "but that adds up to 12, isn't it more likely that this is meant to be felt in some 3 based structure", and listening to it further, these things are always anyone's guess but i would certainly venture that the drummer is feeling 5 and 7. the lyrics/vocals mostly seem to be happiest as 5+7, but some of the vocals are likely meant to go 3+3+3+3. i would even venture a step further and say that the writer(s) have thought about all of this, and these sorts of number games might even be what informs some of the lyrical content

084455.question: how was the writing process for "i'm best friends with my own front door"?
084455.answer: very fast. i had just snapped and said 'i'm going to do these music videos in 2 weeks even though i know it always takes 10 weeks no matter how hard i try to make it 2 weeks or even 4 weeks, but now i'm desperate, it's gonna be 2 weeks or die trying', and so there was no time to waste. and on the selection, i seemed to hate everything (as usual), so because the time was so limited, part of my brain just said 'what song do you wish you could do' (like one that doesn't exist yet), and the first 2 lines wrote themself. So that was the starting point, then i began writing it, and i think after the whole day i still really had barely even wrapped up the first 2 stanzas. not good, because there's only 14 days to do the whole process, ..... write, record everything, all everything, video, ..... entire everything. So i took a panic walk and slapped myself into shape and realized if i can't finish this in the next 4 hours then i'm off the bus pretty much. So basically the first thing that was written after the switch into panic mode was the 'i saw the sign' bit. i think it's evident that this wouldn't have made it into the song if i had had time to think. but in fact, it's this line that is the gateway to the entire mindset of the rest of the song. it sends it off a sort of cliff, and a series of strange things unfold, and due to momentum, when we finally land at the 'outchorus' ('do everything'.... etc), the real-world emotion of the actual scenario seems to realize itself more fully and genuinely, and the song is definitely about itself, as you can see the victory set in towards the end, and yet also admitting how it had seemed like the end of the world just moments ago which i narrowly escaped

084502.question: how do i identify chords in a song? most of the time i can only hear the top note, and chords have always felt very mysterious to me for this reason. can you learn to hear all individual notes, or do you just "feel" the intervals? i found a secret trick yesterday where i play my guess for what the chord is on my keyboard, then listen to the chord in the song, then play my guess again. i could hear if my bottom note was too high or too low. (only tried this with 2-note "chords", though.) do you know any other secret tricks?
084502.answer: yes yes also play/pause, really quick, and just hunt for all the notes. this is how you can get started. and transcribe entire songs this way. then after 30 or 40 or 100 songs you will start to intuitively feel how the chords work and pretty soon you won't have search for individual notes anymore, you can just hear the chord. then after 600 or 1000 songs you will automatically know all the songs you've ever heard, just from memory, without even checking them

084577.question: Hey Bill, do you agree with me that we should switch to ternary numeral system (base 3)? This does indicate that intellectuals are tired of having four as the expected result for two plus two. If we were to use binary, then two won't even exist; but to use ternary, two plus two won't be four anymore; instead it would be 11 (base 3). So conclusion, do you agree with me?

084705.question: Hi Bill! I love your music and also I've read a few of these questions and your music advice seems really solid. My question is, do you have any advice for understanding how time signatures work? I'm new to music theory and having a hard time getting my head around this particular concept.
084705.answer: first get a metronome. that's just like a 'clicker'. just download one and you'll see what i mean. it just makes a constant click. and you can set the speed (tempo). ok now turn it off, and listen to some songs. see if you can find the 'beat', in those songs. the 'beat' is like the steady click, and most songs have it, all the way through. it is what people 'tap their foot' to, or, i think a couple days ago someone accused me of 'nodding my head' up and down while playing music. that would be the same thing. listen to every song you know and see if you can find this pulse. for most songs, it goes all the way through. But, .... there's more.... What if i told you that these beats could be organized in groups of 2. So imagine if you're hearing the steady click, but you're seeing a flash of light on the 1st, 3rd, 5th, 7th, (althernating) clicks. i hope this is making sense so far. or maybe just every alternating click is louder. so like, CLICK click CLICK click CLICK click. it might not actually be louder in the music, but it feels like a miniature starting place, every 2 clicks. it's hard to explain, i just realized. i've been familiar with this probabaly since before i could speak language, so i hope it's something you can get because i actually just realized i have no way of explaining it. Also, just to make sure we're on the same page, try to make sure the tempo is usually somewhere between 70 and 140 -- just listen to those tempos on your metronome to get an idea of roughly the speeds i'm talking about, so when you listen to songs, you can find the beat in that range (not like doubled or quadrupled or something). So as you listen to songs, try to ask yourself, can you feel the clicks, and can you also feel how one out of every 2 clicks seems to feel like the dominant one. Hopefully this is making sense. it's much easier to actually demonstrate than to explain in only words. So i think you'll find that almost every song you can find, has these beats, in groups of 2 like this. Well, if you take it a step further, you will find that these groups of 2 also seem to come in groups of 2. so that makes groups of 4 clicks. see if you can listen to some songs and see if you can find the beat, and see if you can hear which one is the first of the group of 4. see if you can hear it in groups of 4. at least 90% of all songs in the world will use this 4 pattern. This means that the timesignature of the song is 4. actually on paper this is written with two 4s on top of each other, but that's not really that important. the time signature is called "4 4", pronounced "four four". but in actual reality you can just say the song is "in 4". and literally every musician on the planet will know exactly what you mean. Most songs are in 4, kind of like most cars have 4 wheels, and most people walk in a repeating 2 pattern (which, when superimposed on itself at halfspeed, creates 4, which is exactly the way it occurs in music). It's just a natural property of nature that music tends to operate this way also. a "bar" is just 4 beats. so if a song has a time signature of 4 (or "four four", again, it's sort of a long boring historic story as to why it's called that), it means there are 4 beats in a bar. Most music is like this, for most of the time. But, a LOT of songs, ESPECIALLY when transitioning between sections, like going from the verse to the chorus, or from the chorus to the verse, may break this pattern momentarily, in between sections. This is normal. It's like that left-right walking pattern -- it gets interrupted when you get onto your bike, but then while you are on the bike the pattern is back to normal. and then it gets weird again for 1 or 2 steps as you get off the bike. This technically means the time signature changed (to maybe 1, or 5, or whatever you need) just for that one moment when you got off the bike. This again is natural in nature, for patterns to occasionally need to break in order to pass from one scenario to the next. More rarely, you might occasionally find songs that actually seem to consistently have 3 beats per bar. This means the time signature is 3, or, traditionally on paper this is written as 3 4 (the 3 is written directly above the 4, and it's pronounced "three four"). Again, it's kind of a long boring historic story as to why the 4 is written under there, but it's the top number that really tells you how many beats per bar. But if you imagine the tempo differently, you might not need to write it in 3. for example, if it's 3 very quick beats, you might even imagine them all as just 1 beat. and guess what ....... those big 1 beats are definitely going to usually come in groups of 4. so either the time signature is 4 (and the tempo is slow) and the beats happen to be broken in groups of 3 (those would be called 'triplets') OR, you can say it's in a time signature of 3, and the beats go by 3 times quicker ('tempo' would be therefore be 3 times faster on paper), and you are hearing groups of 4 ENTIRE BARS. ..... Now, here's the thing, ... when you're learning about time signatures, it's going to be tempting to ask 'well what would happen if there was a weirder grouping like 5, 7, or 11.' Well, this is ok, and it's a fun question to ask, but there is diminishing effectiveness as the numbers get weirder, although it's tempting to think that's a good idea while you are learning, because your brain is focused on it. However, it still remains true that these weird numbers are very commonly used MOMENTARILY, like when going from one section to the next. Or, just, if you have a special lyric in there that needs more or less time. Music lives and dies by the element of surprise, so this will be necessary. But when it comes to keeping a steady time signature for a long period of time, you will find that 4 will be it, at least 90% of the time. about 8% of the time it will be 3, but again it's always debatable whether it's actually just a slow 4 with triplets in each beat. Less than 1%, you may actually find a consistent 5. and in at least half of those cases of 5, the number 5 will actually be in the title of the song, because as i said, it's usually a very deliberate mental exercise. This is increasingly true as you start to use larger prime numbers (7, 11, 13, etc), and if you see those used steadily over the course of long periods of time (such as an entire song) it becomes increasingly likely that the composer wants you to know they are thinking about the time signature. as tempting and fun as it is, to dwell on these scenarios for the sake of learning, it also seems necessary to mention the significance and importance of '4' because we often overlook this, if we become 'interested' in time signatures, which you may have, based on your question. Now, you may think, 'well, are you saying that we should strive to be boring and normal', and the answer is no. but in the greater scheme of things, if you're gonna be free then probably wouldn't even want to restrict yourself to a time signature at all. so, weirdly, doing a song in 7 and staying in 7 is actually more restrictive than just keeping it in 4...... Four is usually what happens when you are not trying to actively focus on the time signature, AND, what i would like to mention again is that very often you get deviations from this, but NOT in a way that stays that way constantly -- it will be usually just when you need to get from one place to the next. so it's almost not even fair to count that as a 'different time signature', and in many of those cases it's literally not a different time signature because the tempo pauses itself completely for an undefined amount of time. i would estimate that this may happen in at least 30% of all songs, very broadly speaking. in conclusion, the time signature is usually 4, but i don't necessarily expect you to believe me at this point

084758.question: When I make music, I try and start with a melody. Then I tweak it and stuff. Then I start experimenting with it, and then I delete it and try something els, and then I get nothing done. I've been stuck in this stupid loop for months. How do I ever escape? Can I ever escape? How deep does the pit go? I guess I'll never know. Those sound like lyrics though. :)
084758.answer: there is a certain phenomenon i've noticed, in these situations, and the phenomenon is called 'the first version is the best one you're gonna get'. i'll tell you the 2 most distinctive times i remember that being proven for me. the first day writing 'just did a bad thing', i made it through the 1st verse (double verse), through 'cancelled', and sing the connecting riff and suddenly land into this full 16 bar chorus, which fully came to me very quickly, which i was thrilled about, but it absolutely didn't seem to fit with the rest of the song (the 'bad thing' song). it was the entire 'hey, what's the name of this game' section, exactly how you hear it on the recording. that was what originally came, springing straight from that little connecting riff (after 'cancelled'). i was quite disappointed, i loved it but it just didn't seem to fit with that song. so i marked it down as 'hey what's the name of this game', as a different song, to be dealt with another time. Then i tried something totally different there. something about science or something, not anything sounding like the chorus as you know it. tried several different ideas for what could go after 'cancelled'. and by the end of the day, simply nothing was sticking. every attempt seemed to have less validity than the previous. i noticed this decrease in validity as the iterations wore on. so i knew there really was no choice but to return to the 'hey what's the name of this game' and trust that it can go in 'bad thing.' and i'm glad i did. and this is not the first time this has happened, it happens all the time. the most similar time i can think of is in 'sexy pants', almost exactly the same story, with the entire 16 bar thing at 'every day is such a lovely day' etc. that whole thing came very quickly, but i was disappointed to realize it really doesn't belong in that song, so i put it aside and tried to come up with the right thing but each attempt was increasingly more doubtable so i had really no choice but to go back to the first one. i've generally accepted this as a common princicple, that if you find yourself deleting and redoing something several times, you kind of have no choice but to just go with whichever version you thought of first. and just accept it as part of the thrill ride of songwriting, which sometimes is to be forced to work with crap. sometimes the best songwriting is when you think your partner or coworker has just handed you a piece of crap, and now you gotta make it work some how

For example, if you found an apple in the kitchen drawer, and you said 'wow, that's a great apple'. and you get into this whole *apple* project about it. then, 12000000 years down the road, when you're working on the project and you feel a bit confused about the whole apple project, just think back to the original circumstance. and you may be surprised at what details you might have overlooked. such as, in this case, ......................................... the kitchen drawer

084767.question: bill i am in a pickle. i have a great bridge, but it's just floating in a void bridging nothing together and i have no idea what goes on either side of it. it's also instrumental which makes it even harder. i just know it would be an awesome bridge... i fear i may just have to move on with my life. have you ever been in such a predicament? what do you think i should do?
084767.answer: just keep it in the list. i'm sure the idea takes up no more than 1mb max. sure bridge only is probably just about the hardest to work with. but, just play process of elimination. play 'what do we know.' gradually quiz yourself on things about the 'other part' (ANY other part) of the song. for example, does it live mostly on the 1 chord? is it a 4 first? maybe start asking yourself little questions about what should categorically be immediately before it. you will get an average of maybe 23% of an answer to each of these little questions. just keep asking the questions and you will gradually hone in on useful information. how about this: what should come after it. that will still get you close to figuring out everything else. Another general principle to remember is making patterns and breaking them. Whatever patterns are in the part you have, ask yourself what it would mean to break those patterns in the other part. or, this might be a slightly harder question, but what is a pattern such that your section (that you already have) would be good at breaking. Here's another even more scientific approach. just try putting things before it. then analyze exactly why you hated it so much, if at all. whether you liked any of them or hated any of them, with each one you will get just a bit more glimmer of information about what kinds of things are working and what is not

084835.question: Oh my gosh your answer to my question about time signatures was amazing! Thank you! Another music theory question... is it better to "think" in different keys when writing music, or is it better to just start with chord relationships in a familiar key then transpose to a key that fits the emotion better? I have a hard time breaking out of C major.

084837.question: do you have any suggestions on how to set up your music writing area so that you can write music better?
084837.answer: yes. i will tell you my story, in context, so you can make your decision. i used to think it was better to put the desk against the wall, facing toward the wall, because it gives you more space in the room. but then, at some point, right around when i was facing one of the more severe brickwalls in my development as a writer, just 1 day after the really really dark day when i sort of made a declaration that this is impossible and i can't do this, i had a breakthrough and rearranged the desk, to be facing away from the wall. and this changed everything. i didn't expect this but it ended up being the magic key to everything. things seem to be better if the desk faces the generally toward the door (but is on the opposite side of the room). basically if you can imagine it as an office where people might come in to meet with you occasionally. for some reason that makes all the difference

084875.question: is "might quit" in 1/16 triplet? tested that and i get the exact same basic structure
084875.answer: you could think of it that way. there's like 10 ways to write it down, but, unfortunately, this is the part that counts, there's 2 ways to feel it and i don't like one of them. the way it's supposed to be, you might write as 12/8 which actually means there's 4 beats in the bar and each one is broken up into a very quick 3, and just to clarify those 4 beats per bar are clicking at around 108bpm. or if you considered it 54 bpm, that would be a legit sound for the verses, and then you would consider those 16th note triplets. what is unfortunate, i think, is that it's still possible to feel it in larger groups of 3, each having a tiny group of 2. it would feel like a lullaby that way, which is not the way i meant it. i tried to put a very clear count-off at the beginning to avoid this, but i have heard many people hear it the wrong way. just to clarify, this is not their fault, it's mine. customer is always right. i have another upcoming song in this feel, and i will do better next time

084890.question: what is the meaning of life, didn't you say you found it, do you still hesitate to say it?
084890.answer: the thing about it is, when we say "it" it sounds like something you can count. it sounds like 1, really. if someone says "found it", how many things do we think they are talking about? 1, probably. well the thing about the *meaning of life* is, ............. most of the time, the quantity it seems to be dealing with is more 'infinite' in style. which, strangely, can almost appear identical to the number '0', any time you try to quantify it or do any definitive reporting on it.. so it's not so much hesitation, it's more just like that stupid feeling when you're a math teacher and one day you have to say "ok folks, here's something called the 'reflexive property' which says a=a. it literally means things equal themselves. wasn't that important, aren't you glad i said that, don't you feel like that was an important use of time to say that"

084895.question: i am scared of adobe premiere too and i am paying for it. there are so many buttons... my question is how do you go about learning new software? do you watch tutorial videos or just try and learn everything yourself? all the videos i find are like 20 mins just to show where a simple button is
084895.answer: DON'T GET SOMETHING TOO COMPLICATED. a general rule is, try to learn with something free first. because the paid stuff is probably gonna be so complicated it will send your brain into hibernation for 5 to 9 long years i have a new company policy that i only learn software that is open source and scriptable. so the learning process is actually only about 40% learning and 60% creating how i want the software to be the most important thing to do first is figure out the EXPORT. figure out how to export something, to a video file that you can WATCH (not make). step 2 is to make it not blank. by then you will be well on your way. plan to succeed with only 1.7 percent of the features. that's how most of earth works normally, on a day to day basis

085621.question: Hi, I'm a human trying to make music. I normally have a kinda easy time creating the chords on the piano and then writing the lyrics, but what I have a problem with is adding more instruments/effects. I've tried using GarageBand before, but nothing else ever seems to go with my music, and I'm not sure if I'm just not good at music production (I kinda failed that class at school) or if my songs just shouldn't have any instruments besides piano, but my songs tend to get really boring after a while with no instruments. I've probably said a bit more than needed, but I was wondering... can you give me some tips on adding more effects and instruments to songs?
085621.answer: i have an idea....... start with the shortest song you can imagine. start with a song that's only 1 second long, with only 1 word in it. you'll have plenty of time to try out everything imaginable, because it will barely take any time to try each thing. once you find some things that work, expand those techniques into a 2 word song. and so on

085869.question: any thoughts on your song In California? I think i read that it was made a little after history of the entire world, but it kinda has the early bill wurtz vibe
085869.answer: yes here are my thoughts about it. it is an interesting case study in deadlines vs non deadlines, it's also an interesting case study in brute force randomized song selection, and it's also a good case study in making arrangement adjustments at the very last moment. deadlines vs non deadlines: i knew the entire time when i was making history of the world that i wanted to do songs constantly, forever, and i wanted to do this before history of the world, but history of the world became unexpectedly more important. so the entire time i had the idea that i was going to do songs next. so finally when i was done, i immediately jumped into the song. i had a general idea that i was going to use a weekly deadline, but i wasn't ready to do it quite yet. i wanted to take my time and do it 'right'. i got some good things, the initial groove/vamp sound was found then, and some other things, but after several days, maybe even a week, i felt everything slowing down, and i couldn't seem to make good decisions anymore. so i suddenly set a deadline and then demanded to do them weekly after that. Immediately after setting that deadline, i suddenly made a bunch of bold instrumental choices that wouldn't have been made otherwise. some of the percussion fills in the first verse, a lone loud bongo bonk, a hyper spaz hi-hat fill followed by a huge crash, if i remember correctly those are examples of decisions i made immediately after declaring being on a deadline. brute force randomized selection: usually if i try to select the next song without randomized assistance (like, actually choose which one i want to do) it's usually a downward spiral into rejecting everything. every song is too this or too that. too weak, too intense, too emotional, to dumb, too smart, too slow, too fast, too weird, too normal, etc etc. And i have no courage to take any risks. So the alternative to this is just getting a brute force random number. count all the songs in the list, (at this time it was something like 400), and get a computer generated random number from that range, and you MUST do that song. Well, i was willing to accept the result, but the problem here with the result (california) is that the song features a massive marijuana reference. This would be ok except for the fact that i had already had multiple marijuana references in songs before that. Ultimately i went forward with the selection because i felt like i had no other choice, but this highlights a problem with brute force random selection. Yes, it helps you avoid thinking EVERY song is 'wrong', but there's a weird fine line to reckon with because some songs ACTUALLY are 'wrong', considering the previous songs. For example, this song being about california, the following song (also chosen with brute force random) was called "i love you". Well, there is also a song in the list called "California Love" which has nothing to do with those other two. So, imagine for a moment, if "California Love" was picked next, after those other two. that would be terrible, it would look like an obvious deliberate themed connection, which it is not. fortunately the randomizer did not pick that, and the next 2 choices turned out ok. and since then i have developed a hybrid system that allows me to mostly rule out any of these problems before the randomized selection is made making arrangement changes at the last moment: usually, after the instrumental arrangement is done, and the vocals are done, and mixing is done, and i'm in the final troubleshooting stage, there can be an extreme resistence against going back and changing things in the arrangement. you just don't want to re-open what seems like a sealed box. but occasionally it has to be done, and i've learned that i MUST let myself be open to that. this song is a good example: those synth riffs in the background of the "it's alright" parts. Those were added at the very end. like during the final adjustments / mixing / troubleshooting phase. i opened the arrangement again to add those riffs there. and it made a huge difference some additional thoughts about the writing: it's important to point out that this song was essentially written in august 2011 (about 6 years before it was recorded). So this may slightly change the way the lyrics are perceived. Marijuana was not fully legal in any state at that time. and the reason it is about California is because that is the state that was most well known for marijuana usage at the time, because i think it had recently become legal medically. For every other state mentioned in the song, i'm pretty sure, it was still very illegal, especially in Alabama which i believe had some of the toughest marijuana laws at the time. One of the reasons i featured it in the second verse. Also, the final line of the song (love who you want to) was certainly a reference to the legalization of gay marriage, which at the time was only legal in certain places, which is another thing California was known for at the time

085875.question: HELP! I have a song with a strong sixteenth note rhythm in 4/4 at 130BPM. But halfway through, the sixteenth notes stay the same tempo and switch to a triplet rhythm (alternating 1+ 2+ 3+ 4+ and 1 a2 a3 a4 a). How should I write that? Constant triplet brackets in 4/4? 12/16 time signature? A very uncomfortable 6/8?
085875.answer: your description of the change is not entirely clear, but if it's all groups of 3, i would say use 12/8. and if the value of time needs to change, use 'note equals note' notation. for example if you're using 12/8 and you need the new tempo to be dotted quarter = 130, then write quarter note = dotted quarter note, when the transition occurs. However, (and this was unclear to me from your description) if the old 16th note needs to become the new 8th note (in 12/8) then you can write sixteenth note equals eighth note. Or if you use 12/16 you don't need any conversion. it will also be assumed that it's grouped in 3s if you beam them that way

085965.question: What should I do if I feel like my song goes on for too long but I like every individual part of the song?
085965.answer: find the 'split point.' run the song from the beginning and find the first part that really doesn't seem good enough. just before that part, this is the 'split point.' take away everything after that (save it, put it on a shelf, don't promise to use it for this). keep running it from the beginning up to the split point and try to figure out what comes next, with no bias toward what you've shelved. although if the shelved contents screams out to you as the perfect thing for the moment immediately after the split point, then you can use it. but always respect the play through from the beginning, and know the split point
