086004.question: how do you feel about straight 8th notes vs swing feel.

086005.question: I'm looking into different temperaments such as 19-TET. I've been listening to a few pieces in different temperaments but 19-TET seems to resonate particularly well for me for some reason, even though I don't fully get it. I've been trying to figure out how to use it myself but without a custom built 19-TET keyboard, it would be very difficult. Maybe I can manually write notes in a MIDI roll, but I want to be able to improvise. Even with one though, how do scales work? It seems to be still 8 notes, which I suppose maybe makes sense but then again does it and what do you do with all the other notes?!? Why do we use 8? Why do we use 12? I was looking into this and then I found Just Intonation (JI) again - yes I suppose it makes sense why we use 12-TET but why can't we use JI with modern tech? Can't we just change the fundamental when we modulate? Or, is it deeper than that? With JI (in C) does it mean that if I play an Fm7, it wil l still sound wrong as a C#7 would? I can't figure out how to properly play with a Just keyboard without spending $1400 on digital piano that does it for me. I think if our mortal minds could fully grasp this, then we would be able to create even more wonderful music. I think it's transcendental and we will never fully understand. Do you think? Or have I just not studied hard enough? Ahh I've been looking at this for days and I feel like it's at the very fundamental of music in general. My conclusion is quickly becoming "it just does not really make very much sense".

086096.question: What does the bottom part of a time signature even mean? I've watched so many videos on it and I still can't grasp its purpose
086096.answer: that is supposed to be what note a beat is. so if the bottom number is 4, the 'quarter' note is supposed to be the beat. if the bottom note is 8, then the 8th note is supposed to be a beat. so "4/4" is supposed to mean there is 4 beats per bar, and a quarter note is 1 beat. "6/2" would mean there is 6 beats in a bar and the half note is one beat. There are some problems with this system-- one problem is that in some countries the notes are not named like this (quarter, eigth, etc). And the other problem is that when the top number is a multiple of 3 and the bottom note is 8, it's usually not actually the 8th note that gets one beat, it's usually actually 3 eighth notes that get one beat. but at least the bar length will adhere correctly to the number system, so for example what i'm trying to say is, 6/8 in the real world usually does not actually mean 6 beats per bar with the 8th note getting one beat. instead it usually actually means there's 2 beats per bar and the dotted quarter note gets one beat. this is mathematically equivalent, but felt differently, for speed. but let's face it, who really wants to write 2/2.667

086368.question: You said the song you are currently working on is the longest youve written. Was it randomly chosen, or do you have a reason for doing it now?
086368.answer: that's not true. the bob marley song was longer, and another one from 2011 was also longer the selection process was marred with highly potent self-doubting agony, which is to be expected. i did the standard procedure of combing the entire list and selecting ones that seemed like the right choice. then i did a few rounds of writing on those finalists, to boost their status even further. i was expecting to have to randomize amongst those, but i ended up setting a deadline/timelimit on when i had to choose, and just chose. i knew it was the right choice, and yet, the following morning, i reached such high levels of doubt that i actually convinced myself that i CANNOT do that one, and then quickly reminded myself that if i don't stick with that selection then the entire validity of the selection system is broken, and i also had to remind myself that any selection is going to give me various flashes of misery, until i delve into the writing process. i was able to recall that this exact same thing happened with the 'la de da' selection, where i doubted it so badly the next day that i actually changed my mind and then hated that option too and so i had to switch back. basically it all gets better once you start writing on it and start to find solutions for its problems

086387.question: Do you plan the visuals in your videos while you're writing your music? Do the visuals influence the songwriting process? Or are the visuals planned/done after the song is essentially written?
086387.answer: sometimes well, think of it this way, .... there would be no visuals planned BETWEEN the time of song writing and the time of song recording. after the song recording, that is when the visuals happen. but some things were probably obvious during the songwriting process. (i.e. 'lemon song' probably should have a lemon in the video). But here's a new twist that i've found: if you try to come up with visuals at the same time as writing the song, it actually helps you write the song. Even if that visual is not even used.... even if you dont even come up with any specific visual ...... just telling yourself to activate the part of your brain that thinks of visuals, for some reason it makes the songwriting 10x more potent. even if no visual is thought of, it tricks your brain into going to the right place. just to pretend you are supposed to be coming up with the visual. so in other words, when you're writing a song, pretend you're writing a video. it doesn't even matter if you even make a video, just tell your brain you're writing a video, and often you won't even come up with any visual but it still jumpstarts the songwriting when you think that way. hopefully i've explained it. i started doing that with 'best friends with my own front door', and i've been using that trick ever since. it's like opening the door to the next room, to help give you perspective on the room you are in

086471.question: should i learn to notate music on paper or is recording myself good enough? in your opinion are there any advantages/disadvantages of one over the other?
086471.answer: the advantage to notation would be: if you need someone else to be able to play something without having any time to prepare or memorize. CAUTION: this only works on people who can read well enough to do this. which is fewer and fewer people, as recording devices become more and more readily available. Advantage of notation, is that you can read while you are playing, where as you can't really play something from a recording in real-time. Advantages to recording, you can record the music much more accurately, and express things that would be impossible to fully explain in notation

086954.question: hi bill, your keyboard playing is very inspiring; do you have any tips on how to practice hand independence? it feels quite overwhelming as a process, i'm not exactly sure on how to babystep my way into that. thabks
086954.answer: this is actually a relationship for more than 2. your right hand, your left hand, your voice, another person as the bass player, another singer, another person as a guitar/keyboard player, ...... Check around your ensemble (maybe just you) and tally up HOW MANY of those items are in your ensemble. (i listed 6 things, now that i count them). And now, keep in mind that there are maybe only THREE ROLES that those must play, IN TOTAL. not each. Basically it's 3 jobs to do. so think about how many people/things are doing them. If the amount of things/people doing the jobs is more or less than 3, then there will have to be some interesting agreements made. everyone probably can't/shouldn't do all 3 at the same time, unless they are very very coordinated with each other. And yet, on the other hand, if there's only 2 things/people, they will have to juggle the 3 roles. the 3 roles are bass, melody, chords. So let me give you some examples, and my point is that your hands have different jobs depending on the personell situation. so for example: let's say it's just you. and let's say you are using both hands and your voice. that's pretty clear, your left hand takes the bass, your right hand takes the chords mostly, and your voice takes the melody. Well, imagine, instead, that you already have a bass player in the band, and let's say you are NOT singing. In that case, the bass player plays the bass, and YOU will be playing NOT the bass, but the melody and chords -- probably 1 with each hand. This is an entirely different configuration because now you are playing chords with your left hand. Let's imagine a different situation-- let's say you are playing with no bass player, you are not singing, but you have another person who is the singer. In this case, you will be doing bass in left hand and chords on right. Let's look at another example: if it's you on keyboard, and someone else on guitar, and the guitar player is singing. Well, the 2 of you need to come to an agreement and one of you should take care of the bass, and the other should take care of the chords. An important hint is that there should not be more than 1 person taking care of the bass (unless it is written EXACTLY, AND if it's neccesary to be full of BEEF at that particular moment.-- this will only be good for a non-musical sound effect / rumble sound. will not really work musically/tonally.) Also the other combination i forgot to mention is, if you are playing piano by yourself with no other players and not using your voice-- in that case, you will be dividing the 3 roles amongst only TWO players (your 2 hands) so in that case, you sort of have to magically somehow juggle the 3 of them. So, between different combinations of bass, chords, melody, ... and the players: your left hand, your right hand, and your voice, there are many different combinations for what jobs your hands are going to play. So it's important to take a moment to notice which of these scenarios you are in. And beyond that, the strategy is essentially the same, which is to use your imagination and try to play songs in any possible way you can, because someone's gotta do it

086964.question: what would you call a e-g-a-d voicing with bass on e? e-7 add 11 no 5? because sus4 would imply no 3rd, as opposed to no5 wouldnt it?
086964.answer: that would pretty much be the only way to accurately convey the information to a stranger, using only a chord symbol. unfortunately it is probably too long to sight read. i suppose you could write A7sus4/E, but that may or may not send a different kind of message to the reader. My personal short hand for the chord you are talking about is E-sus11 (Emin sus11) however this is NOT something that you can use on a public chart and expect anyone to know what you are talking about, because it does not conform to any kind of standards that anyone knows. sus11 is something i made up, and you can't count on anyone guessing what you mean if you write that. i just use it because i use that all the time (actually with no E in the harmony, just in the bass), and another way of writing that is also Gsus2/E or maybe you could get away with G2/E (in case G2 is accepted as Gsus2 which it may or may not be). also it seems important to prioritize E in the chord symbol to make it plainly clear that this is acting like some kind of E minor chord, because anything else will make the reader have to pause and do some calculations. but as i said earlier, the only way to really do this is exactly the way you said it (add this, minus that, etc) and the reader will definitely have to do some calculations there as well yes

087046.question: give me y2k give me it i need it bill i must have it bill
087046.answer: what happened was, in the late 1900s, as the year 2000 approached, people started realizing that most of the computer systems in the world were actually only using 2 digits for the date. so "75" is assumed to mean 1975. this wasn't a problem when those systems were designed, because probably no one expected them to be still in use by the end of the century. but they were. So the fear was that some terribly unexpected stuff may happen around the world as a result of all the computer systems suddenly thinking it's 1900, instead of 2000. there was a widespread fear that everything would break down. but luckily, through hard work i think, most of the important systems managed to get fixed in time, so there really wasn't any huge catastrophe. This issue was known as the "Y2K" issue, but besides that, Y2K was actually just a nickname for the year 2000. so essentially, Y2K means the year 2000. hope that helps

087100.question: yesterday i was listening to your music while laying on my bed and looking out my window at the night sky, and all of a sudden (while mount st. helens was playing, for some reason) i felt what i can only describe as a "healing stream of tingling sensations" flowing through me; and in that precise moment, for a split second, i knew. i deeply and intuitively knew that everything in existence is exactly as it should be in order to have the best possible case scenario for everything that exists, that the universe is a perfectly choreographed wholesome orchestration of artistic unconditional love; in a non-linear, harmoniously flowing, endless dance of infinite creation. then the intuition slipped away from my experience, and i was like wtf just happened? now i don't really know if there was something truly reasonable in all of that, but it was for sure an interesting experience; and i am positive that your song played a big role in it. so thank yo u for that and, finally the question part, have you ever experienced something even remotely similar while creating your music? take care

087158.answer: a bob ross episode, he's doing a painting (obviously), and he's doing a bush in the lower right, probably a snowy bush, but here's the thing, instead of doing it the normal way, he gets a huge glob of white. like a huge ball of white paint, as big as a golf ball maybe. so he's doing the bush with this massive ball of white paint, and then it actually falls on the floor, he says oops and tries again, also he's talking about another interesting television show on another channel called 'Thursday to Paint', also telling us he doesn't really like that show very much and generally doesn't respect it. So anyway, he's working on doing this bush with a huge white glob of paint, and it falls on the floor a second time, and finally he decides to just, do it the normal way i guess (not with a huge glob), and so that works fine, then he leans down and cleans up those other 2 globs from before and says, embarrassed, 'that was just like Thursday to Paint.' 087401.question: How do I get better at playing double stroke rolls on the drum kit?
087401.answer: just start playing 2 strokes each hand, evenly, at some reasonable pace like 2 per beat, at 120bpm, and just speed up the tempo gradually. your hands will eventually figure out what you need to do. like that time when you learned to walk. actually wait i just remembered, here's a slightly more interesting tip .... try playing it so that the second note is actually the downbeat instead of the first note. so do like a RLLR-RLLR etc pattern, so the second stroke is the one that falls on the downbeat. and then gradually speed up from there. this way is actually very healthy to learn because it probably helps even out the strokes, by psychologically reversing the way your mind thinks of them. i just remembered that probably 80% of the doublestrokes i play are aligned this way, it's just more comfortable for me. it frees the pairs from prison of their pairing, if that makes sense. allows for stronger integration with singles actually, with more possibilities for sure. in other words it will help them not sound like doubles

087402.question: Do you ever get into the habit of turning to a particular motif to the point where almost every time you sit down to write something, you end up playing that? How do I stop doing this?
087402.answer: this may be a slightly unexpected technique, but try writing a song as if it's appearing in a movie or some other type of video-story. imagine the scene, imagine the story, imagine as many things as you can about the world the song may live in. even if none of what you're imagining actually gets mentioned in the song, it still seems to power the songwriting tremendously, and opens up the possibilities you need. less like staring at a wall

087586.question: In the song "at the airport terminal" you used some of the most insightful imagery and lyrics to make a true work of art. my personal favorite being "bvzvbsvzsbvsvbszvsbvzsbsvbzbszbsb" how do you come up with such beautiful art?
087586.answer: basically the thing about that was, i was originally expecting lyrics to fill that melody entirely. i knew the first line (at the airport terminal the planes are landing) and i was expecting more words to go in the second line, and nothing was working. as soon as i had the idea of just doing a plane sound effect there, suddenly the whole verse came together very easily. Sometimes in songwriting it's important to remember to space things out a bit, and it's easy to forget that writing a song is much slower than listening to a song, so sometimes it's good to remind yourself to let an additional moment go by for the previous lyric to be absorbed

087606.question: how do you deal with blender's overwriting behaviour? i've been trying to use the ol "try to just make sure you check before you hit render" policy but it is still amazing how easy it is to hit the wrong directory and overwrite a whole scene :o (i only lost part of a draft render but this is still cause for concern)
087606.answer: right, that's not a realistic workflow that was one of the main reasons i turned away from blender, years ago. But, now i've returned to it in a different light, and i embrace it because of it's vastly powerful scriptability. So what i do is this: the default render folder is the temp folder. those files will disappear soon anyway. As part of the render process, i have an automated process that happens as soon as the render is done, which copies the rendered movie automatically to my preferred folder, and automatically names it according to the time, for example: render20201019203817.mp4

087813.question: why is it so much easier to start a new song than to continue one?? it's driving me crazy. you'd think continuing something would be easier than coming up with something from scratch, but no. i'm guessing you're going to answer with "try making shorter songs", but that doesn't solve the problem because it doesn't train the skill of coming up with "the next part" of a song. i think learning to play already existing songs on an instrument could help train that intuition, what do you think about that?
087813.answer: here's what happened to me. when i was at your stage, one solution is to just finish it in 1 session. i was writing entirely on paper at that time. but i soon got tired of that method (it's a good method, but it results in some pretty mentally insane songs, with all due respect to mental insanity), and i also came up with a lot of choruses, verse fragments, or just intros, and didn't know how or WHEN to deal with them. but here's what i eventually did: i went through all my notes and collected every song or song fragment i had ever written or worked on. and i put them all into a list in chronological order. Then, i just started at the beginning of the list, and 'find the next thing' or, just 'answer the next question' on each of them, before moving onto the next one. this unfortunately would take infinite years, so i shuffled things up a little and did a percentage completion system, etc etc, but still had ways of selecting which one i was doing next. nowadays i'm selecting to record, which means whichever one i select, could be a fragment, is the one i will record. so that puts me in a situation of writing for the recording which is about to happen. I guess what i'm trying to say is, the selection process is so important because if you are not confident about the validity of your selection, then you will run away from the song. So i guess the selection is one half of the challenge. then there's just techniques to do once you're there and you're already sure you're working on the right song, now what do you do? Well it's a lot like being a doctor. you just have to ask good questions. First thing i would check, is, 'is this the beginning', like, does the piece you have belong at the beginning of the song, or in the middle, is it the chorus, etc etc. If it clearly belongs absolutely at the total beginning, then, the process is pretty simple. Just run it through, and stop playing at the end of what you have, and wait for lightning to strike. Then if it doesn't, ask as many questions as you can about what you think you might have been about to hear.... Then what i do, for a re-set, is i walk over and touch the door handle, and come back and run it again from the top, and do the same thing again. It's extremely important that you run it AT TEMPO (at the right tempo) because often what we do in songwriting if we're trying to think of ideas, we run the bit before, over and over and we start doing it faster, which will trick you into then writing things at the wrong tempo and it won't fit with the rest. so make sure all your run throughs are at tempo. it's good to get on the metronome as soon as you can, to preserve, because songwriting is a time warp and it can make things change speed when you didn't mean to. But i didn't mention what to do if the piece you have is NOT the beginning. in this case you are going to have to do a weird backwards puzzle to figure out what comes before. It's almost impossible to figure out what comes before something, actually. one weird trick which might be semi-reliable is to run the chorus and see if you can get a second verse, and then hope that one of the things around there also makes sense as an intro, but at least for me writing backwards is almost impossible

087881.question: I find "just did a bad thing" to be very well orchestrated/composed. How did you figure out which instruments to use in the song and what parts they should play? Do you follow a formula per se or do you do it randomly?
087881.answer: here's what i've discovered: i choose all the instruments i want first. then i go through the song and figure out where each one goes. instead of going to a place, and finding the instrument, i first get the instrument, and then find where it fits. i call this the sprinkle technique. This actually won't take care of the entire song, because if you only do sprinkles, you will usually never end up getting the important mainstays like the kick and bass, etc, but, it is a good technique nonetheless. it is particularly exciting when you do sprinkles first, before doing anything else. by the way this only works if you've written the song first before you start recording it, and have the exact road map

088022.question: do you think there are any songs that simply can't be rendered to work without percussion, eg just keys & vocals alone? if a song seems off without it what can be done that will probably make it nice, if any generalizations can be made here? like bringing it to the point where the song feels like it has bones and isn't a weird pile of flesh, if that makes sense. like how can one troubleshoot this kind of thing if you literally could not give it a beat due to being trapped in a void dimension where all you have is a piano and your floating disembodied head and hands. asking for a friend who lives in the void
088022.answer: no, but, keep in mind you will need to be well open to playing notes that may be very different from what occured on the recording. in other words, of course you can do it, but you can't be afraid to approach it entirely differently it involves mostly the same creativity that is involved in songwriting. somehow you have to make something up maybe all it takes is to be trapped on an island with only the piano and your voice. it's amazing how quick you can come up with good solutions, when you have fewer tools. basically i can promise you 2 things: 1, it can be done, but 2, you may have to re-invent the whole thing, which is really why it's gonna be so much fun

088133.question: In a question from yesterday asking about memorizing major and minor scales, you answered that it would ruin the music and prevent genuine playing. This worries me because the way I try to orient myself on the piano and guitar is by completely relying on memorization of the major scale. For the key of the song and/or the chord of the current measure, I visualize the shape given by the major scale that corresponds with that chord as numbers from 1-7 (along with 9,11,13 I guess, and also stuff like #5, b3, etc.), and so those numbers go on different keys/frets depending on the key/current chord. I wouldn't really be sure how I'd find my way around without this orientation. Is this a bad way to be going about it, and if so, is there another method you would suggest that doesn't rely on the major scale?
088133.answer: it would be bad for me, but, one of the wilder things i've learned in life is that different people are so different basically you could just start with one note. just play that note, now you know how it feels to play that note. so you have 2 options: playing the note, or playing nothing. think of the wonderous portraits you could paint, just from painting and not painting that note. Gradually, when you're ready, add another note to the notes you know. just learn what the notes sound like, 1 note at a time, and let them gradually assimilate themselves into your repetoire. the darn thing happens pretty much automatically the more time you spend around the instrument

088249.question: what do you think about the idea of objectivity in regards to music quality? i remember you saying something here before basically saying that if something is popular, then it must be good, i'm paraphrasing but that was the gist of it i think. but i've also seen you talk about how everyone has different perspectives on things and how everything is good. do you have any thoughts to add about objectivity versus subjectivity in music? or anything creative for that matter?
088249.answer: i never said that i don't agree with that entirely that is a much more attractive idea to endorse objectivity and subjectivity are tools to determine which person is right and which person is wrong. the person who knows the words 'objectivity' and 'subjectivity' is always right, and here's how they do it: first they say 'subjectively', which means people are allowed to disagree. Then, they provide an alternate situation, 'objectively', which means there is only one right answer and you are not allowed to disagree with that. It's sort of like a good cop / bad cop scenario, where the 'subjectivity' scenario gives you a false sense of comfort, thinking it's ok for people to have different opinions, then the hammer comes down when 'objectively' there is only one true opinion, which spells checkmate for the other person of course

088250.question: how does daylight saving time actually work?
088250.answer: during the spring and summer months, the clock tells you a later time than it actually is. so it makes the evening seem a little lighter and the morning a little darker. this is besides the fact that the evening and morning are both already lighter than they were in the winter, but because of daylight saving, the evening is WAY more lighter, and the morning is ..... only a little bit lighter. it shifts the daylight later by 1 hour. in the springtime, when it changes, you will always hear people saying 'wow i can't believe it's still light at this time of evening', and in the fall when it switches back, you will hear people saying, 'wow i can't believe it's already dark at this time of evening.' However, what you may not hear, but is still said, is similar but reversed comments about the morning. But with a different twist, because it goes in the opposite direction of the way it's been heading. so, for example, in the springtime in the morning, after it changes, people in the early morning will be saying 'well, the mornings have been gradually getting lighter these past few weeks, but they just suddenly got darker again, although i know they are still going to gradually get ligher from here.' and in the fall, in the morning, just after it changes back, people in the early morning will say 'well, the mornings have been getting gradually darker over the past few weeks, but suddenly they just got brighter again, although i know they still will continue to get darker from here.'

088505.question: im teaching my nephews piano and i wanted to get your thoughts and ideas on how im approaching it. for the younger ones i am first making sure they know where do is. then the rest of the white notes. teaching them how to sing a major scale. then i invite them to make a song up by plaiyng with the black keys, so they can have pentatonic fun. For the older one, he came to class knowing jingle bells. he likes learning songs. i am thinking of teaching him some chords to play along with jingle bells. but i also am teaching him a bit about the circle of fifths, how it relates to sharps and flats in different keys, and then showing him how jingle bells can be played starting in any note. I am very slowly trying to teach them how to read notes off a pentagram but I feel like that can dampen the excitement for the instrument if it becoems too "academized". I took a look at a teaching book and it doesnt look too fun tbh. maybe the best time to teach them to r ead musi c is when they want to learn a specific song? I can notate it for them and have them read off it? They range ages 4 to 10 probably. Some are more motivated than others but i feel they can all get excited about different aspects of piano/music/learning
088505.answer: it sounds like you are doing great. maybe you could also do some purely rhythmic exercises. rhythms might be a nice starting place for reading also

088586.question: When do you plan to release ur next video. Somewhere around next year?
088586.answer: my first plan was march 26, 2019. then i made some bold new discoveries and worked on it for a long long time, not having any clue of when it would be done. then i made some even bolder discoveries which totally sidelined that video, then after a long long time of further experiments and development, somewhere around august 2020 i threw a dozen panic attacks simultaneously and made another plan for oct 6, 2020. but this was innacurate of course, again because of the fact that the whole process and procedure is essentially brand new. so basically i've been working steadily on the video ever since then, at a somewhat defeated and disheartened pace. so if i were to make up a due date, it would hold no validity at this point due to so many past failures. however, i am still working on the same item since late august 2020, and it is an ordinary song/video of average size. things are going quite well, and some brand new doors have been opened and will continue to open over the next 5 to 10 years, in terms of the content that will be made. however, the other side of the coin is that i am face to face with the imminent threat of complete ineptitude, simply due to my ongoing tendency to overestimate what i am capable of. this has plagued me for my entire life, and probably will require a more definitive solution than i've had before, if i intend to continue producing creatively for the rest of my life. which i do of course, even if just to catch up with the things i've already written. and that's not even including the fact that my propensity for writing has only amplified even more with each passing year, as it always has every week if all goes well

088588.question: You say you are normal a lot, but i don't think you are. it's not normal to isolate yourself and work almost constantly in the pursuit of artistic greatness for years and years . it's not normal to record yourself almost constantly and archive all the recordings, then edit them together later to craft a narrative of your progress. it's not normal to have such a deep analytical understanding of music as you do. it's not normal to have a website dedicated to documenting almost everything you've ever created. Obviously there are people who do this/have done this, but it is a small minority still and thus not normal. it seems like you know you're not normal and that's why you feel the need to keep insisting that you are. i'm not saying it's bad not to be normal, i think it's good, if you were normal then i wouldn't even know who you were or be sending you this message. Are you afraid of being abnormal?
088588.answer: no, i'm extremely proud of it. i've actually been so audaciously proud of it for so many years that my PR team has advised me to please downplay it

088613.question: I think it's ok that you overestimate your own ability because I'd rather have 1 really really good song better than anything I've ever seen before than 10 mediocre songs that were intended to be more than they were
088613.answer: yes but the problem is, if you plan on making 1 thing to be the best, it very often curses that thing. where as if you do many things, you tend to get a lot better at it, and it is increasingly likely that certain ones will shine as 'best', and it would probably actually be different ones for different people. for example, when i'm choosing which song to do, i usually find myself totally paralyzed because i'm afraid it will be the only one. the only way i've ever been able to convince myself to feel comfortable picking a song is to absolutely promise myself that there will be many many songs. if any song attempts to be the only song it will find itself extremely cursed

088678.question: I like that some of your answers are jokes or nonanswers, but also could you maybe just answer the question sometimes? like if i were to ask you what your favorite song that you've made is, you'd say "i would prefer to make a new one to be my favorite," which is fine, but you know that's not the answer we want, so if you were to give us an answer that contains one of the titles of one of your already existing songs?
088678.answer: yes in that case, unfortunately, you just don't want the real answer that's not the way it works. i think you are thinking it from the perspective of someone who did not make the songs, and is just listening to them. i actually make the songs, so, i have to always try to make each one as good as i can. so that's my role in this. Trying to figure out how good any of the songs actually turned out to be, is impossible and pointless, for me. i tried to make each one to be the best song that ever existed. none of them actually turned out that way, but that's just the nature of the job, which continues on into the future in the same fashion

088699.question: Bill, what does creativity mean to you?

088701.question: i've spent basically every bit of time i can in the past few years working on my music, instruments, and mixing as well as getting completely obsessed with video as well. realizing that i will be like this for the foreseeable future (and it keeps getting more obsessive and intense) i feel like i am getting more and more disconnected from reality (whatever that means). while i "know" many people from working on songs and production for other artists, i feel more and more disconnected and unsure of what a friend is and what music even is. this obsession only happened in these past few years, before i had played instruments just because it felt like an obvious thing to do, but without any real intention of making something. people i "used to know" have been very worried about my mental health due to the drastic change over time and how little time i have for anything other than working constantly on art. i find all this extremely hard to explain proper ly to so meone, and i haven't found anyone that seems like they actually understand what i'm trying to do (i don't know if i do sometimes). the thing im worried about is how i can get myself to take breaks effectively and somehow divert my obsessive attention into something "fun" that is unrelated sometimes. nothing is fun unless im working on a project; everything other than that just feels like a crazy waste of time as well. anyway, do you have any suggestions about learning how to effectively take breaks? i've tried various meditation techniques with little success. the only thing that really seems to work decently is going on a reeaaally long walk, and then i sometimes notice that i haven't had a conscious thought in minutes, and it is both a scary and good feeling at the same time.
088701.answer: as long as you are getting enough physical movement, you should be pretty good. it sounds like you know what you're doing

088702.question: As a musician who likes to listen to songs and try to imitate them to a T, your music is the only kind so far I haven't been able to figure out all the notes to. There's just so much unique, complex genius that goes into them. Listening to the first few seconds of "And the Day Goes On," for instance, the snare drum doesn't follow a rhythmic pattern (although it works beautifully), so I have to listen to it 2 seconds at a time to understand it (while isolating it in my mind from the other instruments, which is hard to do when I get mesmerized by the chords). There's also some subtle tambourine and a few short flute notes in there, that you have to listen closely to hear, and then a bunch of different instruments starting to pour in. It's incredible. I'm in awe. Where do you get that otherworldly "feel" for music from? The heavens? Apollo is not the God of music; Bill Wurtz is.
088702.answer: holy ocean replenishment ceremony, you are very friendly it happens automatically over time. it sounds like you already have plenty of belief in what's possible, so you're going to end up learning to do it better and better, over time i think you will soon find out that it's actually you

088703.question: What do you want from life? What drives a man to create with the intensity that you do?

088704.question: are you proud of the music and videos you make? i think you should be but i also know that im never proud of my work
088704.answer: it depends what mood i'm in just keep doing it, eventually you will be, with also feelings of unproud mixed in. this is to drive you to do better. but, it might help if you can find some stories about other artists, artists whom you think are great, and discover all the times they've felt frustrated with their own work. there is no limit to what we can imagine, but there always seem to be limits on what we can physically do. so that can be enormously frustrating. but what makes it work is the imagination of the viewer, which you can play to. this can be easy to forget, because the viewer will never notice it when it works, they'll just think the artist actually did everything. but they didn't, and they were probably very concerned about this at the time

088811.question: How do you deal with stressful situations?

088812.question: how did the sign in im best friends with my own front door get bad bad
088812.answer: i'll tell you exactly how it happened. i was on a brand new break-neck schedule, where i was supposed to finish a song/video every 2 weeks, which was so much tighter than i had ever previously done it (at least 4x quicker), that no one believed was possible. so this is supposedly the first song of this new scheme, which essentially seems more like a dare at this point, because it's so absurd. So i had spent an entire day songwriting and i pretty much only made it through 2 stanzas. so the next day i had to kick myself and realize that this schedule is so ridiculous that i need to finish the song in the next 4 hours or it's pretty much game over. the 'sign' bit is the first bit to be written under that assumption. so in a way you can probably assume that this is the feeling of realizing i am going to have to steamroll the entire remainder of the songwriting process for this song. And i should clarify, steamrolling sometimes leads to fantastic growth, and i am thrilled with where the song ends up going, especially toward the end. and i don't think it would have ever gone like that, had the prior steamrolling not occured. it's a lesson that continues to play out again and again in the creative process, in the context of a world with limited time and resources

088838.question: what is the new video making process like?
088838.answer: first, i think i can do everything. which overwhelms me, because i don't know which thing to do. Then, as i start choosing which thing to do, i realize 'fuck, i can't do that', then try to do another thing, 'fuck, i can't do that', and so on, .... and just after i start to panic that maybe i can't do anything, i am able to realize that there is still a small range of things i CAN do, and that actually solves the original problem of being overwhelmed from having too many things to do

088904.question: How do different sounds make nicer sounds together?
088904.answer: niceness is a product of our consciousness. from what i can tell, the way this game usually works is by making patterns and breaking them. THIS INCLUDES establishing a pattern of how you break the patterns, and then also, if the mood strikes, breaking that pattern as well. So in this way, it's impossible to determine if any 1 item is nice, or if any 2 items together are nice. i can promise you, for as many situations as you might find where 2 items seems nicer than one, there is also a similar sister-scenario out there where 1 thing seems nicer than 2. And it's really the process of Time/Space which allows these effects to unfold

089106.question: what's a song writing process look like for you? do you have something set you do every time or is it just organic?
089106.answer: at any time, anywhere, ideas can fall on me. even in dreams. that is one part of the process. learning to catch these is crucial to this part of the process. about 70% of the strongest ideas come unexpectedly, not during a songwriting session. So they must be captured and cataloged properly. At that time usually no work is done beyond the capture of the idea. Alternatively, to generate ideas, a more deliberate idea generation session can occur. this is planned, when you try to come up with ideas. remembering a key principle which is that songs can come from literally anywhere, there may be various clever strategies about which places to look. the fun part is, because they can come from anywhere, there is no limit to the places you can look. But still, this is just idea generation, separate from the remainder of the songwriting work. it's still just an idea generation session. Then there is the 'work', which is when you tend to entries in the catalog. depending on the situation, you may be tasked to finish an entire item, or just part of it, before moving onto another. But in either case, you are essentially playing hospital with the song. diagnose it, figure out what it is, what it wants to be, what it's meant to be, etc, and make decisions accordingly. 95% of the time i work strictly forwards, only being concerned with what comes next, and continuing along in order, forwards. The only situation where i would be forced to work backwards is if the original idea does not belong at the beginning. then it's a puzzle to fill in what came before, which seems to defy all laws of physics for me. very unusual. but it can be done and there are various tricks which work with varying degrees of effectiveness. So the majority of the songwriting process (basically all of it except the initial idea seed) follows the same idea of figuring out what comes next. so there are a few important practices that always seem to hold true. agree on an exact tempo as soon as you can, and run a metronome to keep from drifting. this avoids a crisis where you've drifted the tempo and now you may be writing at a level of density which is never gonna fit at the same tempo as what you've already written elsewhere in the song. another important concept is the fact that you really only know what's best the FIRST time you hear it. so you have to do whatever you can to protect this authentic, real time run through, from the mindset of never having heard it before. of course, when you're working, you're inevitably gonna hear it many times. a standard trick i use to help 're-set' is to walk to the door and touch the door handle (with the metronome running) and return and run-through from the beginning. it's also important to remember, full run-throughs are much much more valuable than only running the last part. the full-run through is the only thing that's going to truly reveal where we are at, at a certain point in the song, and thus to properly determine what happens (or does not happen) next. Another thing to realize, if nothing seems to be working and you keep trying things and ditching them, it's important to recognize that the ideas get worse the more you reject them. so if you reject 3 ideas, the 4th will be worse. so if you get too deep into a hole of rejecting, it can be useful to recognize that the first one might be the best one you're gonna get, and make extra effort to try to make the first one work, because in that case it's usually your best shot. Finally, another interesting trick which i've been using a lot recently is, pretend it's in a video. pretend it's taking place in a movie, inside a story. This doesn't even mean you're gonna write a video, but sometimes just pretending it's taking place in a video, will immediately cause interesting songwriting to materialize effortlessly. it's bizarre, because many times when this technique is working, it's not even associated with any particular video content. it's just because you told yourself to pretend you are thinking of visual content, this somehow creates an automatic trigger for songwriting

089153.question: do you have tips for getting good at improvising on the piano, more specifically than just doing it a lot for a long time? my practice usually goes like this: i play a note with my right hand, invent melody from there, and try to play accompanying chords with my left hand, slowly enough to not be *completely* riddled with mistakes but fast enough to still sound like music a little. i do that for like 30 minutes a day (is that long enough if i want to get good before i'm dead?). sometimes i instead start with a note with the left hand, invent a bassline from there and play chords with the right hand. and some other times i play a bassline with a melody, mostly without chords but sometimes try to slide one in when i feel adventurous. (i would sing too but i live in circumstances that makes it feel like a bad idea at the moment.) do you have better strategies? thanks if you read all that, even if you don't answer

089360.question: In "La de da de da de da de day oh" you rhymed "mall" 3 times, was there any hidden meaning behind that?
089360.answer: yes, this is what it is: After selecting this song for recording, i felt deep dread and regret the next day. basically there is a lot of anxiety around selecting a song to record and do a music video for, because unfortunately, for some unknown reason, i always make my songrecordings and videos very complicated. so it is a large commitment when choosing a song. At the time of selection, the song was only written up to the end of the first chorus. So i was feeling a deep amount of regret, the day after selecting it. but changing it would increase all doubts all around, because it had been a very thorough selection process, and if i invalidated that it would cast even larger shadows of doubt on the entire ability to select a song. So i was sitting in the waiting chairs for a haircut, just being very unsure of how to carry forward with the song, ... i had already attempted to change my mind earlier in the morning, to a much slower and sadder song. and i found myself circling back again to 'la de da', and just at the exact moment i was getting into the haircut chair, i let my mind turn to what i think might happen next, in the writing. obviously we are going into the second verse. And it's moments like these, when we say 'what if', that suddenly a blitz of writing comes. The first 3 lines of the second verse came at me very quickly. the relentlessness of the word 'mall' had a nice momentum to it, and certainly helped to plunge me into confidence that the song was the right choice, and by the time i got into the chair, i was certain i would be doing that song. the 4th line, however, did not come at all, and i had to force it later in the actual writing session and i am to this day not proud of it. so if i could summerize the answer to your original question, the meaning of the triple mall is 'momentum'

089417.question: do you ever find it difficult to put your song ideas into the song? And if yes how do you manage to do so?
089417.answer: occasionally first, i must figure out whether the 'idea' is supposed to be the beginning of the song, or not the beginning. if it's the beginning, then just run through it in real time and then have more ideas while already in the song. if the idea is the middle, this is much more difficult because then you have to figure out what came before, which is like writing backwards. which for me is almost impossible. but i have developed some tricks for this, such as asking a trillion questions, trying 100 things, or, seeing what comes AFTER, and then continue from there and hope that somewhere along the line a beginning reveals itself in some kind of cyclical construct

089670.question: if you wouldn't mind temporarily stepping out of the mindset of producing your newest and soon-too-be-hopefully-greatest song and video, is there any song you've made in the past that stands out to you in any way; and if so, would you have any thoughts you could share?
089670.answer: yes on 'hallelujah', i decided to START the entire recording process on an EQ setting that mimics the speaker on a smartphone. the reason i did this was to try to have a better guarantee that the arrangement would make sense there (literally no bass). it sometimes stresses me out that that platform is so drastically different from the ones that include the bass (headphones, car speakers, etc). It's almost like if you are doing a TV show and 40% of your audience can't see the color green. If you are making the project on a system where you CAN see the color green, you're gonna have no idea what those greenless viewers are even seeing. Some people check different systems at the very end, and then make 'adjustments', but i figured it's way too late if you check it at the end. so i decided to start the entire process in the bassless mode, to make sure i was making decisions that were strong on that platform. Then turn the bass frequencies back on and then fill in the bass i want for the full-range listeners. This seemed like a good idea but it didn't really go so well and i don't do it anymore. it didn't really harm the sound of the song, but it encouraged me to overthink even more than i normally do

089752.question: ik this is a tired type of question, but whats the inspiration/meaning behind your video Time Mop? it's very different than other things you were making at the time and gives off some weird vibes.
089752.answer: there are 2 elements to that, which came about completely separately. the audio, and the video that goes with it. The audio recording, called "time mop", was part of a series of 4 recordings i made in june 2009. my career felt way way too speculative for many years up until then, and i was getting very desperate to actually make some recordings. so in a fit of rage and desperation, i did "help, i'm trapped in the center of a rectangle", and 3 others, including "time mop". those are just instrumental music pieces, with no video. Then, later, around 2014, after i had finally begun actually making videos, sometimes song-videos, one of the types of videos i was doing would be music videos to go with songs i had already recorded. i had done some of these already, and they all were songs with lyrics. When there's lyrics, it usually gives you a pretty obvious guide for what might happen in the video. But, what if it's an entirely instrumental song? what would the video look like then? So i decided to try. Actually, i just remembered, i had actually begun to do work on this video as early as 2013, in the early stages of experimenting with video. and then i picked it up again after the regular video production schedule was underway. So it was originally an instrumental, in 2009, as a challenge to myself to do ANYTHING (besides textual non-video non-music), and the video in 2013 was a challenge to see if i could do a music video for a song without lyrics
